body:
Hey @sbakharev - thanks for the clear report! ðŸ™‚ 

Resharper and ReportPortal are both third party products in this instance. What result do you get if you run this test with the NUnit Console?

@ChrisMaddock wow, what a fast reaction!

This test:
```csharp
[Test]
[TestCase(TestName = "")]
[Category("DB")]
public void Test1()
{
    TestContext.WriteLine("Test: " + TestContext.CurrentContext.Test.Name);
    Assert.NotNull(null);
}
```

Produces this test context output:
```
Test: 
```

And this is it's section from TestResult.xml (removed newlines of CDATA nodes to simplify reading):
```xml
<test-case id="0-1001" name="" fullname="NUnitEmptyTestNameTest.Class1." methodname="Test1" classname="NUnitEmptyTestNameTest.Class1" runstate="Runnable" seed="1994871090" result="Failed" start-time="2018-10-02 12:35:30Z" end-time="2018-10-02 12:35:31Z" duration="0.103357" asserts="1">
    <failure>
        <message><![CDATA[  Expected: not null But was:  null ]]></message>
        <stack-trace><![CDATA[   at NUnitEmptyTestNameTest.Class1.Test1() in MY_SOLUTION_PATH\NUnitEmptyTestNameTest\Class1.cs:line 13 ]]></stack-trace>
    </failure>
    <assertions>
        <assertion result="Failed">
            <message><![CDATA[  Expected: not null But was:  null ]]></message>
            <stack-trace><![CDATA[   at NUnitEmptyTestNameTest.Class1.Test1() in MY_SOLUTION_PATH\NUnitEmptyTestNameTest\Class1.cs:line 13 ]]></stack-trace>
        </assertion>
    </assertions>
</test-case>
```

The issue is not about 3rd party products, I've described the process just to clarify the context. The issue is about Name property of the ITest and of the TestAdapter. Empty test name is anyway not normal - that's what I'm trying to tell :)

P.S. NUnit console latest version 3.9.0

Thanks. What I was thinking of, was whether this currently causes any issue for NUnit itself, or if it's just a case of third party products which make assumptions that NUnit doesn't guarantee (e.g. Test names not being empty!) Based on the above - it seems to be the former.

That said - I can't think of any sensible use for wanting empty string test names, so think it could be sensible to add this restriction to NUnit - to avoid user error, like you've had above. What do @nunit/framework-team think?
I think requiring a non-whitespace string is sensible.
Great - then let's do it. @sbakharev - is this something you'd be willing to supply a pull request for?

@ChrisMaddock I've never had any deal with NUnit source code except for reading several portions of code to understand how some of the features work. I'll give it a try but first let @nunit/framework-team tell me which one of the two solutions (exception or providing a generated value) suits better.
I think that we would expect the test to be non-runnable, as in your first option.

issue.title: Require non-whitespace string as test name
issue.body:
If the test name is specified - and different from null - then it must
be a non-whitespace string.

Fixes #3038
